Package com.dhemery.expressions

Expression Kit provides methods to compose conditions, evaluate them, and act on the results.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Eventually
    A factory method for default polling schedules.
    Expressions
    Methods to compose conditions, evaluate them, and act on the results.
    Named
    Factory methods to decorate BooleanSupplier, Predicate, and Function objects to make them self-describing.
    PolledExpressions
    Methods to compose conditions, evaluate them by polling, and act on the results.
    Poller
    Repeatedly evaluates a condition until it is satisfied or the polling duration expires.
    SelfDescribingBooleanSupplier
    A BooleanSupplier that can describe itself.
    SelfDescribingFunction<T,R>
    A Function that can describe itself.
    SelfDescribingPredicate<T>
    A Predicate that can describe itself
    TimeFrames
    Factory methods for polling schedules.

    Class Description
    PollingSchedule
    The interval and duration for a poll.

Package com.dhemery.expressions Description

Expression Kit provides methods to compose conditions, evaluate them, and act on the results. These expression methods designed to satisfy three goals:
  • Evaluate the conditions they express
  • Read nicely in the code where they are called
  • Support diagnosis by fully describing the conditions in error, exception, and log messages

Expression Methods

Expression Kit defines four types of expression methods, each with a distinct purpose:

Method name Purpose Result If Satisfied Result If Not Satisfied
assertThat Assert that a condition is true Returns Throws an AssertionError
satisfiedThat Indicate whether a condition is true Returns true Returns false
waitUntil Wait until a condition is true Returns Throws a PollTimeoutException
when Wait until a subject satisfies a precondition before acting on it Returns its subject Throws a PollTimeoutException

Each expression method is named to read nicely in the code where it is called. For example, each of these calls evaluates whether the submit button is displayed: 


 assertThat(submitButton, isDisplayed);

 if(satisfiedThat(submitButton, isDisplayed)) { /* do something /* }

 waitUntil(submitButton, isDisplayed);

 when(submitButton, isDisplayed).click();

Composing Conditions

Each expression method has a number of forms. Each form offers a distinct way to compose the condition for the method to evaluate.

Parameters Composes a Condition That is Satisfied If ...
supplier supplier.getAsBoolean() returns true
subject, matcher matcher.matches(subject) returns true
subject, predicate predicate.test(subject) returns true
subject, function, matcher matcher.matches(function.apply(subject)) returns true
subject, function, predicate predicate.test(function.apply(subject)) returns true

For example, each of these these examples evaluates some condition relating to a submit button: 


 assertThat(submitButton, isDisplayed);

 assertThat(submitButton, backgroundColor, is(standardButtonBackgroundColor));

Self-Describing Conditions

Most expression methods are designed not only to evaluate conditions, but also to describe the conditions they evaluate. For example, when each assertThat, waitUntil and when method throws an error or exception, it includes a description of the condition. Also, each polled expression method is designed to allow users to implement a Poller that logs each evaluation. Such a logging poller may want to describe the polled conditions in its log messages.

In order to ensure that these expression methods can fully describe the conditions they evaluate, they accept only supplier, function, and predicate objects that are able to describe themselves. To support this requirement, Expression Kit defines SelfDescribing specializations of three standard Java functional interfaces:

  • SelfDescribingBooleanSupplier
  • SelfDescribingFunction
  • SelfDescribingPredicate

The only expression methods that can accept bare, non-SelfDescribing suppliers, functions, and predicates are the Expressions.satisfiedThat methods. These methods do not throw exceptions, and do not poll, and so do not require the objects to describe themselves.

Creating Self-Describing Suppliers, Functions, and Predicates

The Named interface offers factory methods to decorate BooleanSupplier, Function, and Predicate objects with the ability to describe themselves. 


 SelfDescribingFunction<String,Integer> length = Named.function("length", String::length);

 SelfDescribingPredicate<String> empty = Named.predicate("empty", String::isEmpty);

Evaluating Immediately or By Polling

Each expression method has forms that accept a PollingSchedule and forms that do not. The effect of passing a polling schedule or not passing one depends on the method.

Method Name Without a Polling Schedule With a Polling Schedule
assertThat Evaluates the condition immediately, without polling Evaluates the condition using the given polling schedule
satisfiedThat Evaluates the condition immediately, without polling Evaluates the condition using the given polling schedule
waitUntil Polls the condition using the default polling schedule Evaluates the condition using the given polling schedule
when Polls the condition using the default polling schedule Evaluates the condition using the given polling schedule

Explicit Polling

When a polling schedule is passed as the first parameter to any expression method, the method evaluates the condition repeatedly, until either the condition is satisfied or the polling schedule's duration expires.

For example, each of these calls polls for up to 10 seconds for the submit button to be displayed: 


 assertThat(within(10, SECONDS), submitButton, isDisplayed);

 if(satisfiedThat(within(10, SECONDS), submitButton, isDisplayed) { ... }

 waitUntil(within(10, SECONDS), submitButton, isDisplayed);

 when(within(10, SECONDS), submitButton, isDisplayed).click();

Implicit Polling

Two types of expression methods, waitUntil and when, are always polled. When called with out a polling schedule, these methods implicitly use the default polling schedule (see below), which they obtain by calling the eventually method.

Each of these evaluates the condition repeatedly until it is satisfied, using the default polling schedule: 


 waitUntil(submitButton, isDisplayed);

 when(submitButton, isDisplayed).click();

Evaluating Immediately

Two types of expression methods, assertThat and satisfiedThat, poll only when passed a polling schedule. When called without a polling schedule, these methods evaluate the condition immediately, without polling.

Each of these calls evaluates the condition immediately, without polling: 


 assertThat(submitButton, isDisplayed);

 if(satisfiedThat(submitButton, isDisplayed) { ... }

Polling Schedules

A polling schedule includes a polling interval and a polling duration. The interval indicates how often to evaluate the condition, and the duration indicates how long to poll.

The Default Polling Schedule

Each implementation of PolledExpressions must implement the eventually method. This method returns a default polling schedule.

This default polling schedule is used implicitly whenever a waitUntil or when method is called without a polling schedule: 


 waitUntil(submitButton, isDisplayed);

 when(submitButton, isDisplayed).click();

The default polling schedule can also be passed explicitly by calling eventually: 


 assertThat(eventually(), submitButton, isDisplayed);

 if(satisfiedThat(eventually(), submitButton, isDisplayed) { ... }

 // Explicit but otherwise unnecessary
 waitUntil(eventually(), submitButton, isDisplayed);

 // Explicit but otherwise unnecessary
 when(eventually(), submitButton, isDisplayed).click();

Time Frames

Polled expressions read nicely when the polling schedule is phrased as a time frame. The TimeFrames interface defines several "time frame" factory methods for polling schedules:

Method Name Creates a Polling Schedule With
eventually The default polling interval The default polling duration
within The default polling interval The given polling duration
checkingEvery The given polling interval The default polling duration

Each method is designed to read reasonably nicely in polled expressions: 


 assertThat(eventually(), submitButton, isDisplayed);

 assertThat(within(10, SECONDS), submitButton, isDisplayed);

 assertThat(checkingEvery(100, MILLIS), submitButton, isDisplayed);

The polling schedule returned by within has a checkingEvery method. This gives a way to specify both the polling interval and duration in a single expression: 


 assertThat(within(10, SECONDS).checkingEvery(100, MILLIS), submitButton, isDisplayed);
